Sandberg served as [[chief operating officer]] (COO) of [[Meta Platforms]], a position from which she stepped down in August 2022.{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2022/08/02/sheryl-sandberg-officially-stepped-down-as-meta-coo-on-august-1-filing-shows/ |title=Sheryl Sandberg officially stepped down as Meta COO on August 1, filing the founder of [[LeanIn.Org]].{{Cite web |url=https://philanthropywomen.org/foundation-leaders/sheryl-sandberg-a-philanthropists-profile/ |title=Sheryl Sandberg Profile |first=Ariel |last=Dougherty Facebook, becoming the company's second-highest-ranking official.{{cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/sheryl-sandberg-facebook-steps-down-55b7f5dd6ca202c442c9705f6920e613|title=Sheryl Sandberg, longtime No. 2 exec at Facebook, steps down|first=Barbara|last=Ortutay|publisher=Associated Press|date=June 1, 2022|accessdate=June 1, 2022|archive-date=June 1, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220601195444/https://apnews.com/article/sheryl-sandberg-facebook-steps-down-55b7f5dd6ca202c442c9705f6920e613|url-status=live}} In June 2012, she was elected to Facebook's [[board of directors]],{{cite news |author=Eldon, Eric |url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/25/facebooks-board-of-directors-adds-its-first-woman-sheryl-sandberg-its-long-time-coo/ |title=Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook's Long-Time COO, Becomes First Woman On Its Board Of Directors |work=TechCrunch |date=June 25, 2012 |access-date=October 7, 2012 |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612143047/https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/25/facebooks-board-of-directors-adds-its-first-woman-sheryl-sandberg-its-long-time-coo/ |url-status=live }} becoming the first woman to serve on its board. As head of the company's advertising business, Sandberg was credited for making the company profitable. Prior to joining Facebook as its COO, Sandberg was vice president of global online sales and operations at [[Google]] and was involved in its philanthropic arm [[Google.org]]. Before that, Sandberg served as research assistant to [[Lawrence Summers]] at the [[World Bank]], and subsequently as his [[chief of staff]] when he was [[Bill Clinton]]'s [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]]. In 2012, she was named in the [[Time 100|''Time'' 100]], an annual list of the most influential people in the world.{{cite news|last=Kent|first=Muhtar|title=Sheryl Sandberg - The 100 Most Influential People|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2111975_2111976_2112093,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419073155/http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2111975_2111976_2112093,00.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=April 19, 2012|access-date=April 20, 2012|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=April 18, 2012}} On [[Forbes Magazine]]'s 2021 billionaires list, Sandberg is reported to have a net worth of [[United Sandberg|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2022-03-07|archive-date=September 18, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190918173142/https://www.forbes.com/profile/sheryl-sandberg/|url-status=live}} In 2022, she announced she would be stepping down as Meta COO in the fall but that she would remain on its board.{{cite news |last1=Isaac |first1=Mike |title=Sheryl Sandberg Steps Down From Meta |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/01/technology/sheryl-sandberg-facebook.html |access-date=1 June 2022 |work=The New York Times |date=1 June 2022 |archive-date=July 28, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220728223222/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/01/technology/sheryl-sandberg-facebook.html |url-status=live }} In January 2024, she announced that she would not stand for re-election on the board in May 2024.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/tech/sheryl-sandberg-to-leave-meta-platforms-board-after-12-years-dda56828|title=Sheryl Sandberg to Leave Meta Platforms Board After 12 Years|work=Wall Street Journal|date=January 17, 2024|access-date=January 17, 2024|archive-date=January 17, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240117233402/https://www.wsj.com/tech/sheryl-sandberg-to-leave-meta-platforms-board-after-12-years-dda56828|url-status=live}} == Early life and education == Sandberg was born in 1969 in [[Washington, D.C.]], to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family,{{cite web|first=Paul|last=Harris|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/03/16/world/the-facebook-executive-on-a-self-help-mission/|title=The Facebook executive on a self-help mission|work=[[The Japan Times]]|date=March 16, 2013|access-date=April 29, 2018|archive-date=March 17, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317082458/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/03/16/world/the-facebook-executive-on-a-self-help-mission/|url-status=live}} the daughter of Adele (née Einhorn) and Joel Sandberg, and the oldest of three children.{{cite news |newspaper=Miami Herald |date=October 27, 2007 |title=Benjamin A. Einhorn - Death Notice - Classified |via=[[Newsbank]] |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MH&s_site=miami&p_multi=MH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=11C94CFD4BC4D528&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D |access-date=March 18, 2013 |archive-date=September 23, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190923004530/http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MH&s_site=miami&p_multi=MH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=11C94CFD4BC4D528&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D |url-status=live }} Her father is an [[Ophthalmology|ophthalmologist]], and her mother, whose grandparents immigrated from [[Belarus]], was a college professor of French language.{{Citation |last= |title=Finding Your Roots {{!}} Dreaming of a New Land {{!}} Season 5 {{!}} Episode 4 {{!}} PBS |url=https://www.pbs.org/video/dreaming-of-a-new-land-isi5dl/ |access-date=2023-08-02 |language=en |archive-date=July 29, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230729094826/https://www.pbs.org/video/dreaming-of-a-new-land-isi5dl/ |url-status=live }} Her family moved to [[North Miami Beach, Florida|North Miami Beach]], Florida, when she was two years old. She attended [[North Miami Beach High School]], from which she graduated in 1987 ranked ninth in her class. She was sophomore class president, became a member of the [[National Honor Society]], and was on the senior class executive board.{{cite web | url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article1939532.html | title=Sheryl Sandberg: From North Miami Beach High to Facebook's No. 2 |work=The Miami Herald |date=February 26, 2012 |access-date=October 8, 2014 |first=John |last=Dorschner |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008235925/http://www.miamiherald.com/news/local/community/miami-dade/article1939532.html |archive-date=October 8, 2014 }} Sandberg taught aerobics in the 1980s while in high school.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/apr2009/tc2009048_429871_page_2.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411015954/http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/apr2009/tc2009048_429871_page_2.htm |url-status=dead |archive-date=April 11, 2009 |title=Sheryl Sandberg on Facebook's Future |work=BusinessWeek |date=April 8, 2009 |access-date=July 22, 2010}} In 1987, Sandberg enrolled at [[Harvard College]]. She graduated in 1991 ''[[summa cum laude]]'' and [[Phi Beta Kappa]]{{cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2011/07/11/a-womans-place-ken-auletta|title=Can Sheryl Sandberg Change Silicon Valley?|magazine=The New Yorker|access-date=February 20, 2020|archive-date=July 14, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714085333/http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2011/07/11/110711fa_fact_auletta?currentPage=all|url-status=live}} with a Bachelor of Arts in economics and was awarded the John H. Williams Prize for the top graduating student in economics.{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/press/info.php?execbios |title=Executive Bios |publisher=Facebook |access-date=July 22, 2010 |archive-date=January 7, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107111027/http://www.facebook.com/press/info.php?execbios |url-status=live }} While at Harvard, she co-founded an organization called Women in Economics and Government. She also met Professor [[Lawrence Summers]], who became her mentor and thesis adviser.{{cite news |last=Hempel |first=Jessi |url=https://money.cnn.com/2008/04/11/technology/facebook_sandberg.fortune/index.htm |title=Sheryl Sandberg: Facebook's new number two to Zuckerberg |publisher=Money.CNN.com |date=April 11, 2008 |access-date=July 22, 2010 |archive-date=October 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191006194123/https://money.cnn.com/2008/04/11/technology/facebook_sandberg.fortune/index.htm |url-status=live }} Summers recruited her to be his research assistant at the [[World Bank]], where she worked for approximately one year on health projects in [[India]] dealing with [[leprosy]], [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]], and [[Visual impairment|blindness]].{{cite magazine |url= http://www.newsweek.com/id/162350 |title= Sheryl Sandberg, An Inside View of Facebook |magazine= Newsweek |date= October 4, 2008 |access-date= July 22, 2010 |archive-date= October 5, 2012 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20121005173343/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2008/10/03/changing-the-world.html |url-status= live }} In 1993, she enrolled at [[Harvard Business School]] and in 1995 she earned her MBA, graduating with the highest distinction. In her first year of business school, she earned a fellowship.{{cite magazine |url=http://ideas.time.com/2013/03/07/confidence-woman/4/ |title=Confidence Woman |magazine=Time |page=4 |date=March 7, 2013 |first=Belinda |last=Luscombe |access-date=October 8, 2014 |archive-date=October 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191006194122/http://ideas.time.com/2013/03/07/confidence-woman/4/ |url-status=live }} ==Career== ===Early career=== After graduating from business school in the spring of 1995, Sandberg worked as a [[management consultant]] for [[McKinsey & Company]] for approximately one year (1995–1996). From 1996 to 2001 she again worked for [[Lawrence Summers]], who was then serving as the [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]] under President [[Bill Clinton]], as his chief of staff. Sandberg assisted in the Treasury's work on forgiving debt in the developing world during the [[Asian financial crisis]]. She later joined Google in 2001, where she was responsible for online sales of Google's advertising and publishing products as well as for sales operations of Google's consumer products and Google Book Search.{{cite magazine|url= http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=27544173 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130502070948/http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=27544173 |url-status= dead |archive-date= May 2, 2013 |title= Executive Profile* Sheryl K. Sandberg, Chief Operating Officer, Facebook, Inc. |magazine= [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |access-date=February 11, 2012}}{{cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/fabulous-life-of-sheryl-sandberg-2014-7|title=Sheryl Sandberg is stepping down as Meta's COO. Here's how she got her start in tech and became No. 2 at one of the world's most influential companies.|website=Business Insider|last=Hartmans|first=Avery|date=June 1, 2022|access-date=July 10, 2022|archive-date=July 10, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220710081106/https://www.businessinsider.com/fabulous-life-of-sheryl-sandberg-2014-7|url-status=live}} During her time at Google, she grew the ad and sales team from four people to 4,000.{{Cite news|url=https://mastersofscale.com/sheryl-sandberg-lead-lead-again/|title=Sheryl Sandberg: Lead, Lead Again {{!}} Masters of Scale podcast — WaitWhat|work=WaitWhat|access-date=2018-03-19|language=en-US|archive-date=October 6, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191006202206/https://mastersofscale.com/sheryl-sandberg-lead-lead-again/|url-status=live}} === Facebook / Meta Platforms === [[File:Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg meets PM Modi.jpg|thumb|Sandberg with Indian Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] in [[New Delhi]], 2014]] In late 2007, [[Mark Zuckerberg]], co-founder and chief executive of Facebook, met Sandberg at a Christmas party held by [[Dan Rosensweig]]. Zuckerberg had no formal search for a Chief Operating Officer (COO), but thought of Sandberg as "a perfect fit" for this role. In March 2008, Facebook announced the hiring of Sandberg for the role of COO and her leaving Google.{{cite web |last=Swisher |first=Kara |author-link=Kara Swisher |url=http://kara.allthingsd.com/20080304/sheryl-sandberg-will-become-coo-of-facebook/?mod=ATD_search |title=Sheryl Sandberg Will Become COO of Facebook |publisher=[[All Things Digital]] |date=March 4, 2008 |access-date=July 22, 2010 |archive-date=February 2, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210202144353/http://kara.allthingsd.com/20080304/sheryl-sandberg-will-become-coo-of-facebook/?mod=ATD_search |url-status=live }} After joining the company, Sandberg quickly began trying to figure out how to make Facebook profitable. Before she joined, the company was "primarily interested in building a really cool site; profits, they assumed, would follow." By late spring,{{when|date=March 2018}} Facebook's leadership had agreed to rely on advertising, "with the ads discreetly presented"; by 2010, Facebook became profitable. According to Facebook, (as of 2012) she oversaw the firm's business operations including [[sales]], [[marketing]], [[business development]], [[human resources]], [[public policy]], and [[communication]]s.{{cite web |url=https://newsroom.fb.com/content/default.aspx?NewsAreaId=1 |title=Management - Facebook Newsroom |publisher=FB.com |year=2012 |access-date=July 24, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616055842/http://newsroom.fb.com/content/default.aspx?NewsAreaId=1 |archive-date=June 16, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} In 2012, she became the eighth member (and the first woman) of Facebook's board of directors.{{cite news |last1=Raice |first1=Shayndi |first2=Joann S. |last2=Lublin |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304782404577489003831226744 |title=Sheryl Sandberg Joins Facebook Board |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=June 25, 2012 |access-date=October 7, 2012 |archive-date=October 6, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191006215051/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304782404577489003831226744 |url-status=live }} In April 2014, it was reported that Sandberg had sold over half of her shares in Facebook since the company went public. At the time of Facebook's IPO, she held approximately 41 million shares in the company; after several rounds of sales she is left with around 17.2 million shares, amounting to a stake of 0.5% in the company, worth about $1 billion.[https://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/sheryl-sandberg-sells-half-her-stake-in-facebook-1.1746213 Sheryl Sandberg sells half her stake in Facebook] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180623221412/https://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/sheryl-sandberg-sells-half-her-stake-in-facebook-1.1746213 |date=June 23, 2018 }}, ''The Irish Times'', April 2, 2014 ''The New York Times'' published a report in 2018 detailing Sandberg's role in handling Facebook's public relations after revelations of [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] and its [[Cambridge Analytica data scandal]].Frankel, Sheera et al. (November 14, 2018) [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/14/technology/facebook-data-russia-election-racism.html "Delay, Deny and Deflect: How Facebook's Leaders Fought Through Crisis"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181114211819/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/14/technology/facebook-data-russia-election-racism.html |date=November 14, 2018 }}. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved November 15, 2018. According to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', during a meeting, Zuckerberg blamed Sandberg personally for the outcome of the scandal,{{Cite news |last=Seetharaman |first=Deepa |title=With Facebook at 'War,' Zuckerberg Adopts More Aggressive Style |language=en-US |work=The Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/with-facebook-at-war-zuckerberg-adopts-more-aggressive-style-1542577980 |access-date=2018-11-19 |archive-date=September 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190926182543/https://www.wsj.com/articles/with-facebook-at-war-zuckerberg-adopts-more-aggressive-style-1542577980 |url-status=live }} and that Sandberg "confided in friends that the exchange rattled her, and she wondered if she should be worried about her job." On November 29, 2018, ''The New York Times'' reported that Sandberg had personally asked Facebook's communications staff to conduct research into [[George Soros]]'s finances days after Soros publicly criticized tech companies, including Facebook, at the [[World Economic Forum]].{{cite news |last1=Rosenberg |first1=Matthew |last2=Confessore |first2=Nicholas |date=November 30, 2018 |title=Sheryl Sandberg Is Said to Have Asked Facebook Staff to Research George Soros |website=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/29/technology/george-soros-facebook-sheryl-sandberg.html |access-date=30 November 2018 |quote=In a statement, Facebook said that the company had already begun researching Mr. Soros when Ms. Sandberg made her request. 'Mr. Soros is a prominent investor and we looked into his investments and trading activity related to Facebook,' the company said. 'That research was already underway when Sheryl sent an email asking if Mr. Soros had shorted Facebook’s stock.' The company said that while Ms. Sandberg "takes full responsibility for any activity that happened on her watch," she did not personally direct any research on Freedom from Facebook, an anti-Facebook coalition whose members were among the subjects of Definers' later work. |archive-date=September 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190926212939/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/29/technology/george-soros-facebook-sheryl-sandberg.html |url-status=live }} In a statement, Facebook said the research into Soros "was already underway when Sheryl [Sandberg] sent an email asking if Mr. Soros had shorted Facebook's stock." On June 1, 2022, Sandberg announced she would be leaving Meta as COO{{cite news |last1=Brian |first1=Murimi |title=Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg steps down after 14 years |url=https://thenetick.co.ke/2022/06/01/sheryl-sandberg-stepping-down-meta-facebook-coo-14-years/ |access-date=4 June 2022 |publisher=The Netick |archive-date=June 4, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220604150859/https://thenetick.co.ke/2022/06/01/sheryl-sandberg-stepping-down-meta-facebook-coo-14-years/ |url-status=live }} in the fall of 2022 but would remain on the board of directors. Stating a reason for stepping down, Sandberg stated "it is time for me to write the next chapter of my life." In January 2024, she announced that she would be stepping down from the board in May and not running for re-election. == Boards == In 2009, Sandberg was named to the board of [[The Walt Disney Company]].{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2315778020091223?type=marketsNews/ |title=UPDATE 2-Disney nominates Facebook's Sandberg to board |work=Reuters |date=December 23, 2009 |access-date=July 22, 2010 |archive-date=January 26, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100126070151/http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2315778020091223?type=marketsNews/ |url-status=live }} She also serves on the boards of [[Women for Women International]], the [[Center for Global Development]], and [[V-Day (movement)|V-Day]]. She was previously a board member of [[Starbucks]],{{cite web |last=Arrington |first=Michael |url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/03/27/facebook-coo-sandberg-joins-starbucks-board-of-directors/ |title=Facebook COO Sandberg Joins Starbucks Board Of Directors |publisher=Techcrunch.com |date=March 27, 2009 |access-date=July 22, 2010 |archive-date=September 18, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918042610/http://techcrunch.com/2009/03/27/facebook-coo-sandberg-joins-starbucks-board-of-directors/ |url-status=live }} [[Brookings Institution]], and [[Ad Council]]. ==Other work and ventures== [[File:Sheryl Sandberg Gives UC Berkeley Commencement Keynote Speech.webm|thumb|Sandberg gives [[UC Berkeley]] Commencement Keynote Speech in 2016]] In 2008, Sandberg wrote an article for ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' in support of her mentor, Larry Summers, who was under fire for his comments about women.{{cite news |url= https://www.huffingtonpost.com/sheryl-sandberg/what-larry-summers-has-do_b_142126.html |title= Sheryl Sandberg: Larry Summers' True Record on Women |work= Huffington Post |date= December 8, 2008 |access-date= July 22, 2010 |archive-date= June 2, 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100602200105/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sheryl-sandberg/what-larry-summers-has-do_b_142126.html |url-status= live }} She was a keynote speaker at the Jewish Community Federation's Business Leadership Council in 2010.[http://www.jewishfed.org/community/page/blc-videos#Sandberg "Sheryl Sandberg BLC Breakfast"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116151226/http://www.jewishfed.org/community/page/blc-videos |date=January 16, 2013 }} (video). 2010. Business Leadership Council, Jewish Community Federation and Endowment Fund. In December 2010, she gave a [[TED (conference)|TED]] speech titled "Why we have too few women leaders."{{cite news| url=http://www.ted.com/talks/sheryl_sandberg_why_we_have_too_few_women_leaders.html| title=Sheryl Sandberg: Why we have too few women leaders| publisher=TED| date=December 21, 2010| access-date=March 12, 2013| archive-date=June 18, 2012| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120618205641/http://www.ted.com/talks/sheryl_sandberg_why_we_have_too_few_women_leaders.html| url-status=dead}} In May 2011, she gave the Commencement Address at the [[Barnard College]] graduation ceremony.{{cite web |url=http://barnard.edu/headlines/facebook-executive-barnard-graduates-world-needs-you-run-it |title=Facebook Executive to Barnard Graduates: "This world needs you to run it" |publisher=Barnard College |date=May 17, 2011 |access-date=October 7, 2012 |archive-date=January 10, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130110001529/http://www.barnard.edu/headlines/facebook-executive-barnard-graduates-world-needs-you-run-it |url-status=dead }} She spoke as the keynote speaker at the Class Day ceremony at the Harvard Business School in May 2012.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Db0_RafutM | The book argues that barriers are still preventing women from taking leadership roles in the workplace, barriers such as discrimination, blatant and subtle sexism, and sexual harassment.{{cite book|last=Sandberg|first=Sheryl|title=Lean In: Women Work and the Will to Lead|url=https://archive.org/details/leanin00sher|url-access=registration|year=2013|publisher=Knopf|page=[https://archive.org/details/leanin00sher/page/8 8]|isbn=9780385349949 }} Sandberg claims there are also barriers that women create for themselves through internalizing systematic discrimination and societal [[gender roles]].
